title: Jess Phillips mulling run for Labour leadership if Corbyn loses next election
text:
Ms Phillips resigned from Mr Corbyn’s shadow cabinet in 2016 (Picture: PA)

Labour MP Jess Phillips has revealed she may run to replace Jeremy Corbyn as party leader if he stands down after the next general election.

The long-standing critic of Mr Corbyn said he should resign if Labour is not the biggest party in the Commons after votes are cast.

Shadow chancellor John McDonnell said both he and the party leader would quit if Labour loses the next election, which has not yet been scheduled.

Speaking on Friday at the Cheltenham Literature Festival about her plans, Ms Phillips said: ‘I’d have to see how the land lay at that moment.’

‘What I don’t want to be is just a personality in politics. We have gone too far down that rabbit hole.

‘If I stand it has to be not just because people trust me, people do trust me, it isn’t just because people feel connected with that.

Ms Phillips made headlines after criticising Boris Johnson’s language in the Commons last month (Picture: PA)

‘That’s not enough, it has to be about having a genuine plan for the future for our country.

‘At that time, I would make that assessment about whether I was the best thing for the future of the country.’

She added, laughing: ‘That’s a big ask of someone but I am incredibly arrogant.

‘My husband is dead against it. He’s not a member of the Labour Party but he does have a union vote.

‘He would vote for me in an election but I’m not sure he voted Labour at the last one.’

The Birmingham Yardley MP said it is ‘not impossible’ for the party to become the largest one at the next poll but that a hung parliament is the most likely outcome.

‘When I look at the polls, and I see the Tories are surging forward at the moment, I actually can’t see the numbers where they make up the seats that they’ll lose in Scotland.’

Corbyn’s right-hand man in Cabinet has said the pair will resign if they don’t win the next poll (Picture: Getty)

‘If it was proportional representation then the Tories would end up the biggest party, but our system is weird.’

Ms Phillips said last month that even if Labour were the biggest party after the poll, she ‘can’t see a way’ for Mr Corbyn to win outright as he would struggle to beat his better-than-expected performance in 2017’s snap election.

She added that Labour MPs should always campaign for their own party but called on residents in Uxbridge, Boris Johnson’s constituency, to vote tactically to unseat the PM.

The MP also accused the PM of leading a government which is deliberately stoking division.

‘There has always been aggression and violence towards Members of Parliament, that bit isn’t particularly new,’ she explained.

‘The bit that is new is that people’s political careers are currently riding on people hating politicians and are stepping that up for their own purposes, and that I don’t think has been true before.

‘It pays Boris Johnson’s bills for people to hate me, which is s***. There is no way to avoid some of the risk.

‘It’s just constant and you can never tell what is real and what isn’t, and within that chaos lies fear. That is psychological warfare essentially.’

description: Birmingham Yardley Labour MP Jess Phillips thinks Jeremy Corbyn is unlikely to win the next general election outright.
